themes.title: Porcelain as a Cultural Connector
points: Yuhuchun bottles from the Yuan dynasty were highly prized and exported globally, reaching places like Japan, India, and even Kenya. Highlight their role in connecting cultures through trade.
Discuss the Fonthill Vase, one of the earliest Chinese porcelain vessels exported to Europe, emphasizing its transformation into a silver-gilt ewer for European royalty.
Relate porcelain trade to historical topics like the Silk Road and maritime trade routes, helping students connect the objects to broader historical themes.

themes.title: Symbolism and Techniques in Porcelain Decoration
points: Explain the wucai ('five-color') palette, focusing on the use of red, yellow, and green enamels, and its connection to imperial commissions during the Ming dynasty.
Discuss the symbolism of the imperial five-clawed dragon on Ming dynasty plates, tying it to Chinese concepts of power and authority.
Introduce the Qingbai wares' icy blue-green glaze and their association with jade, a material historically revered in Chinese culture.

themes.title: Porcelain Production and Innovation
points: Describe the firing techniques of Qingbai wares, such as firing upside down to save kiln space, and the use of copper or silver rims to cover unglazed areas.
Highlight the Yuan dynasty's use of cobalt blue for underglaze decoration, made possible by reopened trade routes with Central Asia.
Discuss how potters adapted designs from Islamic calligraphy and metalwork, showcasing cultural exchange and innovation in porcelain production.

themes.title: Porcelain as a Reflection of Society
points: Explore the vase depicting literati in mountainous landscapes, emphasizing how these scenes reflect the societal values and aspirations of the scholarly elite.
Discuss how porcelain decoration served as political commentary during the transitional period, reflecting the shift in patronage from the imperial court to merchants and the literati-gentry.
Relate the humble fishermen and lofty scholars depicted on porcelain to broader themes of social hierarchy and daily life in historical China.

themes.title: Hands-On Engagement and Visual Connections
points: Encourage students to compare the icy blue-green Qingbai glaze to jade, discussing why jade was significant in Chinese history.
Ask students to identify the colors in wucai porcelain and discuss their symbolic meanings in Chinese culture, particularly the prominence of red as a color of luck and celebration.
Use the vase with literati scenes to spark a discussion on how art can tell stories about people's lives, values, and dreams.
